facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the High Court of Bombay dismissing a petition under Article 227.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave, from the judgment of the High Court of Bombay dismissing a petition filed under Article 227 of the Constitution praying for issue of an approprivate writ or order quashing the order dated 28-2-1968 passed by the Full Bench, Small Causes Court, Bombay, in appeal No. 95 of 1963 from the order dated 21-2-1963 passed by the Judge, Small Causes Court, Bombay, in R.A.E. Suit No. 9293 of 1959.

facts.text: Full Bench Small Causes Court Bombay passed order dated 28-2-1968 in appeal No. 95 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: quashing the order dated 28-2-1968 passed by the Full Bench, Small Causes Court, Bombay, in appeal No. 95 of 1963 from the order dated 21-2-1963 passed by the Judge, Small Causes Court, Bombay, in R.A.E. Suit No. 9293 of 1959.

facts.text: Judge Small Causes Court Bombay passed order dated 21-2-1963 in R.A.E. Suit No. 9293 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: from the order dated 21-2-1963 passed by the Judge, Small Causes Court, Bombay, in R.A.E. Suit No. 9293 of 1959.

facts.text: Plot of land admeasuring 2108 square yards in Survey No. 171, Hissa No. 7, at Ghatkopar.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal we are companycerned with a plot of land admeasuring 2108 square yards in Survey No. 171, Hissa No. 7, at Ghatkopar.

facts.text: Plot belonged to Jamnadas Chhotalal Dani.

anchor.surface_text: This plot belonged to one Jamnadas Chhotalal Dani.

facts.text: On 15-11-1948, Jamnadas executed two leases in favour of Bhawani Laksamsi and Maojibhai Jethabhai, defendants 1 and 2.

anchor.surface_text: On 15-11-1948, Jamnadas executed two leases in favour of one Bhawani Laksamsi and Maojibhai Jethabhai, defendants 1 and 2.

facts.text: First lease subject matter two plots: 2108 sq yd and another 805 sq yd.

anchor.surface_text: The subject matter of the first lease was two plots, the one referred to above and another in the same area measuring 805 square yards.

facts.text: Second lease subject matter a third plot in the same area.

anchor.surface_text: The subject matter of the second lease was a third plot in the same area.

facts.text: Leases for period of ten years, rent for first plot Rs. 75/- a month.

anchor.surface_text: The leases were for a period of ten years and in respect of the first plot, the rent payable was Rs. 75/- a month.

facts.text: Leases had option clause to surrender by 30-9-1953.

anchor.surface_text: In both the leases there was an option clause which entitled the lessees to surrender the leased property by 30-9-1953.

facts.text: Lessees surrendered the two plots other than the concerned plot on 15-1-1951.

anchor.surface_text: The lessees surrendered the two plots, other than the plot with which we are ,concerned, in pursuance of the option clause, on 15-1-1951, with the result that the lease in respect of the first plot companytinued.

facts.text: Jamnadas died on 14-8-1951.

anchor.surface_text: Jamnadas died on 14-8- 195 1,

facts.text: Before death, Jamnadas made gift of leased property to three respondents.

anchor.surface_text: but before his death he had made a gift of the leased property in favour of the three respondents.

facts.text: Lease determined by efflux of time on 30-9-1958.

anchor.surface_text: The lease in respect of the plot in question here determined by efflux of time on 30-9-1958.

facts.text: Lessees continued in possession paying rent Rs. 75/- per month after 30-9-1958.

anchor.surface_text: But the lessees companytinued to remain in possession paying rent at the rate of Rs. 75/- per month.

facts.text: On 7-8-1959, lessors gave notice to terminate tenancy by end of September 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On 7-8-1959, the lessors gave numberice purporting to Terminate the tenancy by the end of September, 1959.

facts.text: Notice stated lessees sub-let premises and lessors required plot for construction.

anchor.surface_text: They stated in the numberice that the lessees had sub-let the premises and that the lessors required the plot for the purpose of putting up companystructions on it.

facts.text: Lessors filed suit on 22-10-1959 in Small Causes Court Bombay since lessees did not vacate.

anchor.surface_text: Since the lessees did number vacate the premises, the lessors filed suit on 22-10-1959 in the Small Causes Court of Bombay.

facts.text: Lessees contended no sub-letting and lessors did not bona fide require for construction.

anchor.surface_text: The lessees companytended that they did number sub-let the premises and that the lessors did number bona-fide require the premises for the purpose of companystruction.

facts.text: Trial court held no clear evidence of subletting but plaintiffs bona fide required plot for constructing new building u/s 13(1)(1) Bombay Rents Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that there was numberclear evidence of the subletting of the premises, but that the plaintiffs required the plot bona fide for companystructing a new building within the meaning of ,clause  1  of sub-section  1  of Section 13 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates  Control  Act, 1947, hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Trial court held tenancy terminated by efflux but lessees continued by immunity under Act, not holding over s116 TPA despite rent acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt also held that the tenancy terminated by efflux of time, but that the lessees companytinued in possession by virtue of the immunity from eviction companyferred by the Act and so, they were number holding over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act, numberwithstanding the fact that rent was accepted by the lessors from month to month after 30-9-1958,

facts.text: Full Bench Small Causes Court confirmed decree of trial court.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the Full Bench of the Small Causes Court companyfirmed the decree of the trial companyrt.

facts.text: Original lease granted for erecting a saw mill - manufacturing purpose.

anchor.surface_text: the original lease was granted for erecting a saw mill-a manufacturing purpose

facts.text: High Court held no new tenancy by holding over, no contractual tenancy, no notice entitled.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of  the opinion that in view of the decision of this Court in Ganga Dutt Murarka v. Kartik Chandra Das l  numbercase was made out for new tenancy by holding over under section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act as the appel- lants had obtained the status of irremovability under the Act, and as there was numbercontractual tenancy, the tenants were number entitled to any numberice.

issues.text: Whether the lessees had sub-let the premises

anchor.surface_text: They stated in the notice that the lessees had sub-let the premises and that the lessors required the plot for the purpose of putting up constructions on it. Since the lessees did not vacate the premises, the lessors filed suit on 22-10-1959 in the Small Causes Court of Bombay.

issues.text: Whether the lessors bona fide required the premises for the purpose of construction under clause (1) of sub-section (1) of Section 13 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: lessors did not bona-fide require the premises for the purpose of construction. They also contended that by the acceptance of rent by the lessors after the termination of the tenancy by efflux of time, a fresh tenancy was created...plaintiffs required the plot bona fide for constructing a new building within the meaning of clause 1 of sub-section 1 of Section 13 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947

issues.text: Whether a fresh tenancy by holding over was created under section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act by acceptance of rent after termination of the contractual tenancy by efflux of time

anchor.surface_text: The court also held that the tenancy terminated by efflux of time, but that the lessees continued in possession by virtue of the immunity from eviction conferred by the Act and so, they were not holding over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act, notwithstanding the fact that rent was accepted by the lessors from month to month after 30-9-1958

issues.text: Whether the appellants were entitled to six months notice expiring with the end of the year of the tenancy as the original lease was for manufacturing purpose and the holding over tenancy inherited that purpose

anchor.surface_text: that the original lease was granted for erecting a saw mill-a manufacturing purpose and so the lease created by holding over was, by implication, also for a manufacturing purpose, and therefore, lessees were entitled to six months notice expiring with the end of the year of the tenancy, and that the tenancy created by holding over was not validly determined by the one months notice.

issues.text: Whether the conditions for the application of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act are fulfilled

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the question here is whether the conditions for the application of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act are fulfilled. Learned counsel for the appellants argued that whenever rent is accepted by a landlord from a tenant whose tenancy has been determined, but who continues in possession, a tenancy by holding over is created.

arguments.claim: No holding over created; manufacturing purpose notice issue does not arise

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Ganga Dutt Murarka v. Kartik Chandra Das, which followed the principles laid down by the Federal Court in Kai Khushroo Bezonjee Capadia v. Bai Jerbai Hirjibhoy Warden and another is correct

holdings.text: There was no holding over by the appellants under section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Acceptance of rent after contractual tenancy expiry under rent control does not create new tenancy as it lacks bilateral assent with landlord unequivocally recognizing tenant's tenancy right; tenant continues as statutory tenant.

holdings.text: The decision in Ganga Dutt Murarka v. Kartik Chandra Das is correct and does not require reconsideration

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Ganga Dutt Murarka v. Kartik Chandra Das, Which followed the principles laid down by the Federal Court in Kai Khushroo Bezonjee Capadia v. Bai Jerbai Hirjibhoy Warden and another is correct and does not require reconsideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms prior Supreme Court and Federal Court precedents on S116 TPA requiring bilateral contract for holding over; rejects call for reconsideration as principles correctly applied.

holdings.text: The question of six months notice under section 106 TPA for manufacturing purpose tenancy does not arise
holdings.reasoning_summary: No holding over tenancy created, hence no contractual tenancy to which S106 notice requirements apply.

holdings.text: Conditions for application of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act are not fulfilled

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the question here is whether the conditions for the application of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act are fulfilled. Learned counsel for the appellants argued that whenever rent is accepted by a landlord from a tenant whose tenancy has been determined, but who continues in possession, a tenancy by holding over is created.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S116 requires bilateral act: tenant's offer by holding over and landlord's unequivocal assent via rent acceptance as from lessee; mere rent payment/receipt under statutory protection insufficient without evidence of intent for new contractual tenancy.

holdings.text: Manujendra Dutt v. Purendu Prosad Roy Chowdhury distinguished; section 116 not applicable to statutory tenancies post-efflux

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellants, on the basis of the decision of this Court in Manujendra Dutt v. Purendu Prosad Roy Chowdhury others that if in the case of a tenancy to which Rent Restriction Acts applied, the Provision of section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act was applicable, there is nothing incongruous in making section 116 also applicable in the case of a statutory tenancy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Manujendra involved option for renewal and notice under lease; here tenancy determined by efflux, no such renewal, S116 conditions not met unlike renewal scenario.

anchor.surface_text: B. 428, Morriwon v. Jacobs, 1945 1 K. B. 577 and Mangilal v. Sugan Chand, A.I.R. 1965 S.C. 101, applied.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, come to the conclusion that there was no holding over by the appellants and if that be so, the question whether the tenancy created by holding over was for manufacturing purpose and therefore the landlord was bound to give six months numberice for the determination of

outcome.relief_summary: No tenancy by holding over created; appellants not entitled to six months notice; eviction decree of lower courts upheld
directions: Appellants granted time to vacate the premises as per their undertaking given on July 31, 1969

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the question here is whether the conditions for the application of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act are fulfilled. Learned counsel for the appellants argued that whenever rent is accepted by a landlord from a tenant whose tenancy has been determined, but who continues in possession, a tenancy by holding over is created.

We, therefore, come to the conclusion that there was no holding over by the appellants and if that be so, the question whether the tenancy created by holding over was for manufacturing purpose and therefore the landlord was bound to give six months numberice for the determination of
